channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Egypt’s Sisi Sworn In as President
item.description: Egypt’s former army chief Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi was installed as president for a four-year term, taking the reins of power in a nation roiled since 2011 by deadly unrest and economic woes.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: Egypt’s newly sworn-in president, Abdel-Fattah el-Sissi, reviewed honor guards Sunday at the presidential palace in Cairo.

item.title: As Bowe Bergdahl Heals, Details Emerge of His Captivity
item.description: Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl told medical officials he was locked in a metal cage in total darkness for weeks at a time as punishment for trying to escape, according to officials briefed on his condition.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: Bergdahl Was in Unit Known for Its Troubles
item.description: The issues faced by Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl’s unit in many ways reflected the problems of the Pentagon’s strategy writ large across Afghanistan at that moment of the war.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: Bowe Bergdahl, left, in 2009. His former platoon mates gave sharply contradictory accounts of how he viewed the war.

item.title: Urged to Multiply, Iranian Couples Are Dubious
item.description: The country’s leadership is offering incentives to begin and enlarge families, but experts say little will change while economic prospects are grim.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:credit: Morteza Nikoubazl for The New York Times
item.media:description: A nurse with a newborn in Tehran. With the economy weak and the future uncertain, Iranians are having fewer children.

item.title: Nigerian Newspaper Says Army Blocked Distribution
item.description: The newspaper, Weekly Trust, said soldiers raided its work sites just days after it published an article that accused army generals of corruption.
item.dc:creator: By AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE

item.title: Somali Pirates Release Sailors
item.description: Details of how the 11 men were freed were not available, but no ransom is believed to have been paid.
item.dc:creator: By AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE

item.title: Across Iraq, Insurgents Show Reach in Attacks
item.description: Militants stormed the grounds of a university in Ramadi, briefly holding some students hostage, officials said.
item.category: Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: Students escaping over a wall on Saturday at the University of Anbar, where Iraq security forces clashed with armed militants.

item.title: In South Sudan, a Ghost of Wars Past: Child Soldiers
item.description: The United Nations Children’s Fund (Unicef) estimated last month that 9,000 children had been recruited into armed forces or other groups to fight in the South Sudan conflict.
item.dc:creator: By ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lat Padang, a soldier with the opposition army in South Sudan who says he is 18, at a hospital in Bentiu after being wounded in battle.

item.title: Opinion: How to Beat Malaria, Once and for All
item.description: We have to shift from controlling the disease to eliminating the parasite.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By FRANÇOIS H. NOSTEN

item.title: Opinion: A View From Gitmo
item.description: The Bergdahl swap highlights how inmates are hostage to politics.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By RAMZI KASSEM

item.title: Haiti Elections in Doubt as Ex-Presidents Stir Pot
item.description: Political uncertainty reigns as the current president jousts with opponents over the staging of an overdue election, which has brought waves of foreign dignitaries to attempt to defuse the crisis.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

item.title: For Afghan Lovers, Joy Is Brief, Ending in Arrest
item.description: Mohammad Ali, 21, was captured by his male in-laws and dragged to a police station, where he was accused of kidnapping his wife, Zakia, 18, whom he had married for love.
item.dc:creator: By JAWAD SUKHANYAR and ROD NORDLAND
item.media:credit: Andrew Quilty for The New York Times
item.media:description: Zakia, 18, took refuge in a women’s shelter in Kabul after the arrest of her husband, Mohammad Ali, on a kidnapping charge.

item.title: U.S. Crew Is Arrested on Honduras River Job
item.description: A salvage company has a contract to dredge the Patuca River and raise valuable mahogany and cedar logs, but weapons on the company ship mean time in jail.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Britain Frees Pakistani in Inquiry
item.description: Altaf Hussain, the leader of Kirachi’s dominant political party, was released on bail four days after his arrest in Britain on allegations of money laundering.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Poroshenko Takes Ukraine Helm With Tough Words for Russia
item.description: Petro Poroshenko was sworn in amid a continuing separatist insurrection in eastern Ukraine by pro-Russian fighters.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Petro O. Poroshenko, Ukraine’s fifth president, saluted the crowd at his inauguration ceremony.

item.title: Indians Riot Over Power Cuts During Heat Wave
item.description: With temperatures soaring to 117 degrees Fahrenheit, thousands in northern India stormed electricity substations and took power company officials hostage.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: With Nuclear Talks Sputtering, U.S. and Iran Plan Meeting
item.description: A session with American and Iranian delegations in Geneva this week is intended to breathe life into multilateral negotiations over Iran’s nuclear program.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Obama and Putin Meet Briefly at D-Day Event
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia met with Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine, and Mr. Putin also had an informal conversation with President Obama at the D-Day commemoration ceremony in France.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER
item.media:description: President-elect Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine, on Friday passed President Vladimir V. Putin at a D-Day event in France.

item.title: Watching the World’s Game, in the World’s City
item.description: Passion for soccer runs deep in New York. There are 32 teams, in eight groups; we have chosen one nation from each group and provided a local prism to view the games through.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ROBBINS and MARC SANTORA
item.media:credit: Clockwise from top left: Uli Seit and Emon Hassan for The New York Times; Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times; Michael Nagle for The New York Times
item.media:description: Clockwise from top left: Players at Macombs Dam Park in the Bronx; Champions League fans at Lunasa, in the East Village; the back room at Caffé Romeo, in Bensonhurst; at Miss Favela, beneath the Williamsburg Bridge.

item.title: Open Source: Russian State Media Focuses Attacks on Kerry’s Spokeswoman
item.description: Russian state television devoted an unusual amount of time this week to attacks by Russian bloggers on a State Department spokeswoman, Jen Psaki.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: Jen Psaki, a State Department spokeswoman, at a briefing in Washington in February.

item.title: Andrei N. Mironov, Soviet-Era Political Prisoner and Activist, Dies at 60
item.description: Mr. Mironov caught on early to the absurdities of Soviet life and later became active in the samizdat movement.
item.dc:creator: By SOPHIA KISHKOVSKY
item.media:description: An arrangement at a memorial service in Moscow for Andrei N. Mironov.

item.title: World Briefing: Iraq: Attacks Kill at Least 27 People
item.description: Two car bombings against members of an ethnic minority in northern Iraq and militant attacks on Iraqi soldiers and police officers killed at least 27 people on Friday, Iraqi officials said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Spain: Citizenship Plan for Sephardic Jews
item.description: Spain’s cabinet on Friday approved a bill allowing descendants of Jews forced into exile centuries ago the right to dual citizenship.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Quick History: Warfare’s Never-Ending Story
item.description: A World War II commemoration, and echoes of the Cold War.
item.dc:creator: By FRANCIS X. CLINES
item.media:description: Fireworks at Omaha Beach, for the anniversary of D-Day.

item.title: Egyptian Election Law Helps to Block Opposition
item.description: The new law allows authorities to bar the candidacy of supporters of the Muslim Brotherhood, the Islamist group that dominated Egypt’s free elections after the 2011 uprising.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
